Official NASA shuttle status reports posted sci.space.news frequently. DOES SHUTTLE ROLL JUST AFTER LIFTOFF? following answer translation provided Jenks (). Ascent Guidance Flight Control Training Manual, 2102, \tDuring vertical rise phase, launch attitude \tcommanded until I-loaded V(rel) sufficient assure launch tower \tclearance achieved. Then, tilt maneuver (roll program) \torients vehicle heads down attitude required generate \tnegative q-alpha, which turn alleviates structural loading. Other \tadvantages with this attitude performance gain, decreased abort \tmaneuver complexity, improved S-band look angles, crew view \tthe horizon. tilt maneuver also required start gaining \tdownrange velocity achieve main engine cutoff (MECO) target \tin second stage. This really good answer, it\'s couched NASA jargon. I\'ll interpret. 1)\tWe wait until Shuttle clears tower before rolling. 2)\tThen, roll Shuttle around that angle attack \tbetween wind caused passage through atmosphere (the \trelative wind) chord wings (the imaginary line \tbetween leading edge trailing edge) slightly \tnegative angle negative q-alpha).\tThis causes little \tdownward force (toward belly Orbiter, \tdirection) this force alleviates structural loading. \tWe have careful about those wings they\'re about \tmost delicate part vehicle. 3)\tThe attitude (after roll) also allows carry more \tmass orbit, achieve higher orbit with same mass, \tto change orbit higher lower inclination than would \tthe case didn\'t roll (performance gain). 4)\tThe attitude allows crew less complicated \tflight path they execute more dangerous abort \tmaneuvers, Return Launch Site (decreased abort maneuver \tcomplexity). 5)\tThe attitude improves ability ground-based radio \tantennae have good line-of-sight signal with S-band radio \tantennae Orbiter (improved S-band look angles). 6)\tThe attitude allows crew horizon, which \thelpful (but mandatory) part piloting flying machine. 7)\tThe attitude orients Shuttle that body \tmore nearly parallel with ground, nose east \t(usually). This allows thrust from engines velocity \tin correct direction eventually achieve orbit. Remember: \tvelocity vector quantity made both speed direction. \tThe Shuttle have large horizontal component \tvelocity very small vertical component attain orbit. This begs question, isn\'t launch oriented give this nice attitude begin with? does Shuttle need roll achieve that attitude? answer that pads were leftovers from Apollo days. Shuttle straddles flame trenches Solid Rocket Motor exhaust, Space Shuttle Main Engine exhaust. (You effects this daytime launch. exhaust dirty gray garbage, SSME exhaust fluffy white steam. Watch difference between [Orbiter side] bottom [External Tank side] stack.) access tower other support service structure oriented basically same they were Saturn V\'s. side note: Saturn V\'s also roll program. Don\'t I\'m Shuttle guy.) checked with buddy Ascent Dynamics.\tHe added that roll maneuver really maneuver three axes: roll, pitch yaw. roll component that maneuver performed reasons stated. pitch component controls loading wings keeping angle attack (q-alpha) within tight tolerance. component used determine orbital inclination. total maneuver really expressed quaternion, grad-level-math concept combining three rotation matrices four-element array. '**************************** SPHINX *************************** \tSphinx user-friendly, state-of-the-art image processing analysis package that runs across spectrum high performance computer platforms operating UNIX X-Window System. \tIt created meet daily research needs scientists conducting climate investigations using satellite data remote sensing techniques. \t\t Intuitive Graphic Interface \tSphinx features interactive interface with pop-up menus point-and-click dialog boxes which makes image processing analysis simple fast. \tThis accessible menuing enables build attractive image layouts quickly while also providing flexibility returning main menu conduct other image analysis processing operations. \t\t Image Format Compatibility \tUsing smart read/write functions, Sphinx allows easily open save image files variety formats using bit, integer real data values. Sphinx also reads writes common TIFF formats well compresses decompresses image formats save disk space. \t\t Image Analysis Processing \tFor image pixel analysis, Sphinx package includes assortment processing tools that perform useful statistical mathematical filtering operations, such Fourier transforms, convolution product principal component analyses. interactive interpreter both algebraic equations images allows user manipulate combine individual data channels interactively. Standard FORTRAN notation used formula entry trig onometric transcendental functions. \t\t Satellite Spectra Orbit Analysis \tSphinx possesses functions simulate satellite signal sensitivity various meteorological satellites (e.g., GOES, METEOSAT, NOAA, Spot etc.). simulations conducted selection standard atmospheric surface conditions instrument spectral bands. geometry model computes solar zenith angles, warping, orbit simulation, image projection. \t\t Easy External Program Interfacing \tSphinx allows users flexibility integrate externally developed software algorithms processing converting satellite observations. Sphinx exports imports image files image parameters external programs using special interface functions. \t\t Quick Quality Presentation \tSphinx rapidly displays, manipulates, enhances high-resolution multispectral images color tables. Using 8-bit 1024x1024 image planes graphics plane, package conveniently combines color images, graphics text generate sharp digital images articles reports. Sphinx\'s graphics editor provides complete flexibility modifying integrating vector graphics analysis plots with images, such histograms radial graphs. package supplies color gray scale output standard inkjet laser printers. \tOther Capabilities Sphinx also performs image animation, external graphics importing, mosaic fitting... what else? \t\t Software Support Development Sphinx developed Laboratoire d\'Optique Atmospherique (LOA) Universite Lille, France. package received critical feedback support from scientists French national laboratory, Centre National Recherche Scientifique (CNRS), French space agency, Centre National d\'Etudes Spatiales (CNES). LOA, Sphinx undergoes continued refinement development meet changing research needs advances computer technology. package, which features on-line help, supported Internet address  through which questions answered version updates provided without delay. \t\t Performance Tested \tCNES selected Sphinx analyze process satellite data collected during upcoming ADEOS/POLDER satellite mission. Today, Sphinx package NASA Goddard Space Flight Center widely used many French laboratories, including Centre Recherche Physique l\'Environnement, Ecole Normale Superieure Laboratoire Etudes Recherches Teledetection Spatiale, Laboratoire Meteorologie Dynamique. TEST VERSION SPHINX AVAILABLE loasil.citilille.fr (134.206.50.4) anonymous (bin SPHINX ALL_SPHINX.tar.Z) TEST VERSION OUTPUT FILES DISABLE. HOWEVER VISUALISATION GRAPHIC FUNCTIONS AVAILABLE. THIS SUFFICIENT WORK WITH. INTERESTED KEEPING SPHINX, SEND YOUR EMAIL WILL RECEIVE NEWS ABOUT PACKAGE EVOLUTION.'

'Archive-name: space/probe Last-modified: $Date: 93/04/01 14:39:19 PLANETARY PROBES HISTORICAL MISSIONS This section lightly adapted from original posting Larry Klaes (), mostly minor formatting changes. Matthew Wiener () contributed section Voyager, section Sakigake obtained from ISAS material posted Yoshiro Yamada (). PLANETARY MISSIONS MARINER (VENUS, MARS, MERCURY FLYBYS ORBITERS) MARINER first U.S. attempt send spacecraft Venus, failed minutes after launch 1962. guidance instructions from ground stopped reaching rocket problem with antenna, onboard computer took control. However, there turned guidance software, rocket promptly went course, Range Safety Officer destroyed Although sometimes claimed have been incorrect FORTRAN statement, actually transcription error which (indicating smoothing) omitted from expression R-dot-bar (nth smoothed value derivative radius). This error software treat normal minor variations velocity they were serious, leading incorrect compensation. MARINER became first successful probe flyby Venus December 1962, returned information which confirmed that Venus very (800 degrees Fahrenheit, revised degrees world with cloud-covered atmosphere composed primarily carbon dioxide (sulfuric acid later confirmed 1978). MARINER launched November 1964, lost when protective shroud failed eject craft placed into interplanetary space. Unable collect Sun\'s energy power from solar panels, probe soon died when batteries solar orbit. intended Mars flyby with MARINER MARINER sister probe MARINER reach Mars 1965 took first close-up images Martian surface all) flew planet. probe found cratered world with atmosphere much thinner than previously thought. Many scientists concluded from this preliminary scan that Mars dead world both geological biological sense. MARINER sent Venus 1967. reconfirmed data that planet collected five years earlier MARINER plus information that Venus\' atmospheric pressure surface least times that Earth\'s, equivalent being 3,300 feet under surface ocean. MARINER were sent Mars 1969 expanded upon work done MARINER four years earlier. However, they failed take away concept Mars dead planet, first made from basic measurements MARINER MARINER ended Atlantic Ocean 1971 when rocket launcher autopilot failed. MARINER sister probe MARINER became first craft orbit Mars 1971. returned information Planet that other probe done before, revealing huge volcanoes Martian surface, well giant canyon systems, evidence that water once flowed across planet. probe also took first detailed closeup images Mars\' small moons, Phobos Deimos. MARINER used Venus gravity assist Mercury 1974. probe return first close-up images Venusian atmosphere ultraviolet, revealing previously unseen details cloud cover, plus fact that entire cloud system circles planet four Earth days. MARINER eventually made three flybys Mercury from 1974 1975 before running attitude control gas. probe revealed Mercury heavily cratered world with mass much greater than thought. This would seem indicate that Mercury iron core which makes percent entire planet. PIONEER (MOON, SUN, VENUS, JUPITER, SATURN FLYBYS ORBITERS) PIONEER through failed meet their main objective photograph Moon close-up they reach enough into space provide information area between Earth Moon, including data Allen radiation belts circling Earth. three craft failures with their rocket launchers. PIONEER launched October 1958, PIONEER November PIONEER December PIONEER Moon probe which missed Moon became first U.S. spacecraft orbit 1959. PIONEER originally designed flyby Venus, mission scaled down instead studied interplanetary environment between Venus Earth 36.2 million kilometers 1960, record until MARINER PIONEER through were placed into solar orbit from 1965 1968: PIONEER still transmitting information this time. PIONEER (would have been number suffered launch failure 1969. PIONEER became first spacecraft flyby Jupiter 1973. PIONEER followed 1974, then went become first probe study Saturn 1979. Both vehicles should continue function through 1995 heading into interstellar space, first craft ever PIONEER Venus (1978) (also known PIONEER Venus Orbiter, PIONEER burned Venusian atmosphere October 1992. made first radar studies planet\'s surface probe. PIONEER Venus (also known PIONEER sent four small probes into atmosphere December 1978. main spacecraft burned high atmosphere, while four probes descended parachute towards surface. Though none were expected survive surface, probe make transmitted 67.5 minutes ground before batteries failed. RANGER (LUNAR LANDER IMPACT MISSIONS) RANGER were test probes RANGER lunar impact series. They were meant high Earth orbit testing 1961, rocket problems left them useless orbits which quickly decayed. RANGER launched January 1962, intended land instrument capsule surface Moon, problems during launch caused probe miss Moon head into solar orbit. RANGER take some images Moon flew camera unfortunately aimed deep space during attempt. RANGER launched April 1962, same purpose RANGER suffered technical problems enroute crashed lunar farside, first U.S. probe reach Moon, albeit without returning data. RANGER launched October 1962 similar RANGER lost solar panel battery power enroute eventually missed Moon drifted into solar orbit. RANGER through more modified lunar missions: They were send back live images lunar surface they headed towards impact with Moon. RANGER failed this objective 1964 when cameras operate. RANGER through performed well, becoming first U.S. lunar probes return thousands lunar images through 1965. LUNAR ORBITER (LUNAR SURFACE PHOTOGRAPHY) LUNAR ORBITER through were designed orbit Moon image various sites being studied landing areas manned APOLLO missions 1969-1972. probes also contributed greatly understanding lunar surface features, particularly lunar farside. five probes series, launched from 1966 1967, were essentially successful their missions. They were first U.S. probes orbit Moon. were eventually crashed into lunar surface avoid interference with manned APOLLO missions. SURVEYOR (LUNAR SOFT LANDERS) SURVEYOR series were designed primarily APOLLO lunar module could land surface Moon without sinking into soil (before this time, feared some that Moon covered great layers dust, which would support heavy landing vehicle). SURVEYOR successful proving that lunar surface strong enough hold spacecraft from 1966 1968. Only SURVEYOR were unsuccessful missions. rest became first U.S. probes soft land Moon, taking thousands images scooping soil analysis. APOLLO landed feet from SURVEYOR 1969 returned parts craft Earth. SURVEYOR last series, purely scientific mission which explored Tycho crater region 1968. VIKING (MARS ORBITERS LANDERS) VIKING launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida August 1975 TITAN 3E-CENTAUR rocket. probe went into Martian orbit June 1976, lander down western slopes Chryse Planitia July 1976. soon began programmed search Martian micro-organisms (there still debate whether probes found life there not), sent back incredible color panoramas surroundings. thing scientists learned that Mars\' pinkish color, dark blue they originally thought (the pink sunlight reflecting reddish dust particles thin atmosphere). lander down among field sand boulders stretching cameras could image. VIKING orbiter kept functioning until August 1980, when attitude-control propellant. lander switched into weather-reporting mode, where been hoped would keep functioning through 1994- after November 1982, errant command been sent lander accidentally telling shut down until further orders. Communication never regained again, despite engineers\' efforts through 1983. interesting side note: VIKING 1\'s lander been designated Thomas Mutch Memorial Station honor late leader lander imaging team. National Space Museum Washington, D.C. entrusted with safekeeping Mutch Station Plaque until attached lander manned expedition. VIKING launched September 1975, arrived Martian orbit August 1976. lander touched down September 1976 Utopia Planitia. accomplished essentially same tasks sister lander, with exception that seisometer worked, recording marsquake. orbiter series attitude-control leaks 1978, which prompted being shut down that July. lander shut down April 1980. orbits both VIKING orbiters should decay around 2025. VOYAGER (OUTER PLANET FLYBYS) VOYAGER launched September 1977, flew past Jupiter March 1979 Saturn November 1980. VOYAGER launched August 1977 (before VOYAGER flew Jupiter August 1979, Saturn August 1981, Uranus January 1986, Neptune August 1989. VOYAGER took advantage rare once-every-189-years alignment slingshot from outer planet outer planet. VOYAGER could, principle, have headed towards Pluto, opted sure thing Titan close Between probes, knowledge giant planets, their satellites, their rings become immense. VOYAGER discovered that Jupiter complicated atmospheric dynamics, lightning aurorae. Three satellites were discovered. major surprises were that Jupiter rings that active sulfurous volcanoes, with major effects Jovian magnetosphere. When probes reached Saturn, they discovered over 1000 ringlets satellites, including predicted shepherd satellites that keep rings stable. weather tame compared with Jupiter: massive streams with minimal variance 33-year great white spot/band cycle known). Titan\'s atmosphere smoggy. Mimas\' appearance startling: massive impact crater gave Death Star appearance. surprise here stranger aspects rings. Braids, kinks, spokes were both unexpected difficult explain. VOYAGER thanks heroic engineering programming efforts, continued mission Uranus Neptune. Uranus itself highly monochromatic appearance. oddity that magnetic axis found highly skewed from already completely skewed rotational axis, giving Uranus peculiar magnetosphere. channels were found Ariel, Miranda bizarre patchwork different terrains. satellites more ring were discovered. contrast Uranus, Neptune found have rather active weather, including numerous cloud features. ring arcs turned bright patches ring. other rings, other satellites, were discovered. Neptune\'s magnetic axis also skewed. Triton canteloupe appearance geysers. (What\'s liquid 38K?) VOYAGERs expected last about more decades. Their on-target journeying gives negative evidence about possible planets beyond Pluto. Their next major scientific discovery should location heliopause. SOVIET PLANETARY MISSIONS Since there have been many Soviet probes Moon, Venus, Mars, will highlight only primary missions: SOVIET LUNAR PROBES LUNA Lunar impact attempt 1959, missed Moon became first craft solar orbit. LUNA First craft impact lunar surface 1959. LUNA Took first images lunar farside 1959. ZOND Took first images lunar farside 1965 since LUNA also test future Mars missions. LUNA First probe soft land Moon 1966, returned images from surface. LUNA First probe orbit Moon 1966. LUNA Second successful Soviet lunar soft landing mission 1966. ZOND First successful circumlunar craft. ZOND through accomplished similar missions through 1970. probes were unmanned tests manned orbiting SOYUZ-type lunar vehicle. LUNA First probe land Moon return samples lunar soil Earth 1970. LUNA accomplished similar mission 1972. LUNA Delivered first unmanned lunar rover Moon\'s surface, LUNOKHOD 1970. similar feat accomplished with LUNA 21/LUNOKHOD 1973. LUNA Last Soviet lunar mission date. Returned soil samples 1976. SOVIET VENUS PROBES VENERA First acknowledged attempt Venus mission. Transmissions lost enroute 1961. VENERA Attempt image Venus during flyby mission tandem with VENERA Probe ceased transmitting just before encounter February 1966. images were returned. VENERA Attempt place lander capsule Venusian surface. Transmissions ceased just before encounter entire probe became first craft impact another planet 1966. VENERA First probe successfully return data while descending through Venusian atmosphere. Crushed pressure before reaching surface 1967. VENERA mission profiles similar 1969. VENERA First probe return data from surface another planet 1970. VENERA accomplished more detailed mission 1972. VENERA Sent first image Venusian surface 1975. also first probe orbit Venus. VENERA accomplished similar mission. VENERA Returned first color images Venusian surface 1982. \t\tVENERA accomplished similar mission. VENERA Accomplished radar mapping with VENERA sections \t\tplanet\'s surface 1983 more detailed than PVO. VEGA Accomplished with VEGA first balloon probes Venusian atmosphere 1985, including landers. Flyby buses went become first spacecraft study Comet Halley close-up March 1986. SOVIET MARS PROBES MARS First acknowledged Mars probe 1962. Transmissions ceased enroute following year. ZOND First possible attempt place lander capsule Martian surface. Probe signals ceased enroute 1965. MARS First Soviet Mars probe land albeit crash Martian surface. Orbiter section first Soviet probe circle Planet 1971. MARS First successful soft landing Martian surface, lander signals ceased after seconds 1971. MARS Attempt orbiting Mars 1974, braking rockets failed fire, probe went into solar orbit. MARS First fully successful Soviet Mars mission, orbiting Mars 1974. Returned images Martian surface comparable U.S. probe MARINER MARS Landing attempt 1974. Lander crashed into surface. MARS Lander missed Mars completely 1974, went into solar orbit with flyby bus. PHOBOS First attempt land probes surface Mars\' largest moon, Phobos. Probe failed enroute 1988 human/computer error. PHOBOS Attempt land probes Martian moon Phobos. probe enter Mars orbit early 1989, signals ceased week before scheduled Phobos landing. While there been talk Soviet Jupiter, Saturn, even interstellar probes within next thirty years, major steps have been taken with these projects. More intensive studies Moon, Mars, Venus, various comets have been planned 1990s, Mercury mission orbit land probes tiny world been planned 2003. many changes former Soviet Union (now Commonwealth Independent States) will affect future their space program remains seen. JAPANESE PLANETARY MISSIONS SAKIGAKE (MS-T5) launched from Kagoshima Space Center ISAS January 1985, approached Halley\'s Comet within about million March 1986. spacecraft carrying three instru- ments measure interplanetary magnetic field/plasma waves/solar wind, which work normally now, ISAS made Earth swingby Sakigake January 1992 into orbit similar earth\'s. closest approach 23h08m47s (JST=UTC+9h) January 1992. geocentric distance 88,997 This first planet-swingby Japanese spacecraft. During approach, Sakigake observed geotail. Some geotail passages will scheduled some years hence. second Earth-swingby will June 1993 (Earth\'s radius)), third October 1994 Re). HITEN, small lunar probe, launched into Earth orbit January 1990. spacecraft then known MUSES-A, renamed Hiten once orbit. probe looped from Earth made first lunary flyby March where dropped midget satellite, HAGOROMO. Japan this point became third nation orbit satellite around Moon, joining Unites States USSR. smaller spacecraft, Hagoromo, remained orbit around Moon. apparently broken transistor radio caused Japanese space scientists lose track Hagoromo\'s rocket motor fired schedule March spacecraft\'s tracking transmitter failed immediately. rocket firing Hagoromo optically confirmed using Schmidt camera (105-cm, F3.1) Kiso Observatory Japan. Hiten made multiple lunar flybys approximately monthly intervals performed aerobraking experiments using Earth\'s atmosphere. Hiten made close approach moon 22:33 (UTC+9h) February 1992 height from moon\'s surface (35.3N, 9.7E) fired propulsion system about minutes craft into lunar orbit. following orbital calculation results after approach: \tApoapsis Altitude: about 49,400 \tPeriapsis Altitude: about 9,600 \tInclination\t: 34.7 ecliptic plane) \tPeriod\t\t: days PLANETARY MISSION REFERENCES also recommend reading following works, categorized three groups: General overviews, specific books particular space missions, periodical sources space probes. NASA National Aeronautics Space Administration Lyndon Johnson Space Center Houston, Texas Announcement Mission Specialist Pilot Astronaut Candidates ================================================================== Astronaut Candidate Program --------------------------- National Aeronautics Space Administration (NASA) need Pilot Astronaut Candidates Mission Specialist Astronaut Candidates support Space Shuttle Program. NASA accepting continuous basis plans select astronaut candidates needed. Persons from both civilian sector military services will considered. positions located Lyndon Johnson Space Center Houston, Texas, will involved 1-year training evaluation program. Space Shuttle Program Description --------------------------------- numerous successful flights Space Shuttle have demonstrated that operation experimental investigations space becoming routine. Space Shuttle Orbiter launched into, maneuvers Earth orbit performing missions lastling days. then returns earth ready another flight with payloads flight crew. Orbiter performs variety orbital missions including deployment retrieval satellites, service existing satellites, operation specialized laboratories (astronomy, earth sciences, materials processing, manufacturing), other operations. These missions will eventually include development servicing permanent space station. Orbiter also provides staging capability using higher orbits than achieved Orbiter itself. Users Space Shuttle\'s capabilities both domestic foreign include government agencies private industries. crew normally consists five people commander, pilot, three mission specialists. occasion additional crew members assigned. commander, pilot, mission specialists NASA astronauts. Pilot Astronaut Pilot astronauts server both Space Shuttle commanders pilots. During flight commander onboard responsibility vehicle, crew, mission success safety flight. pilot assists commander controlling operating vehicle. addition, pilot assist deployment retrieval satellites utilizing remote manipulator system, extra-vehicular activities, other payload operations. Mission Specialist Astronaut Mission specialist astronauts, working with commander pilot, have overall responsibility coordination Shuttle operations areas crew activity planning, consumables usage, experiment payload operations. Mission specialists required have detailed knowledge Shuttle systems, well detailed knowledge operational characteristics, mission requirements objectives, supporting systems equipment each experiments conducted their assigned missions. Mission specialists will perform extra-vehicular activities, payload handling using remote manipulator system, perform assist specific experimental operations. Astronaut Candidate Program =========================== Basic Qualification Requirements -------------------------------- Applicants MUST meet following minimum requirements prior submitting application. Mission Specialist Astronaut Candidate: Bachelor\'s degree from accredited institution engineering, biological science, physical science mathematics. Degree must followed least three years related progressively responsible, professional experience. advanced degree desirable substituted part experience requirement (master\'s degree year, doctoral degree years). Quality academic preparation important. Ability pass NASA class space physical, which similar civilian military class flight physical includes following specific standards: Distant visual acuity: 20/150 better uncorrected, correctable 20/20, each eye. Blood pressure: 140/90 measured sitting position. Height between 58.5 inches. Pilot Astronaut Candidate: Bachelor\'s degree from accredited institution engineering, biological science, physical science mathematics. Degree must followed least three years related progressively responsible, professional experience. advanced degree desirable. Quality academic preparation important. least 1000 hours pilot-in-command time aircraft. Flight test experience highly desirable. Ability pass NASA Class space physical which similar military civilian Class flight physical includes following specific standards: Distant visual acuity: 20/50 better uncorrected correctable 20/20, each eye. Blood pressure: 140/90 measured sitting position. Height between inches. Citizenship Requirements Applications Astronaut Candidate Program must citizens United States. Note Academic Requirements Applicants Astronaut Candidate Program must meet basic education requirements NASA engineering scientific positions specifically: successful completion standard professional curriculum accredited college university leading least bachelor\'s degree with major study appropriate field engineering, biological science, physical science, mathematics. following degree fields, while related engineering sciences, considered qualifying: Degrees technology (Engineering Technology, Aviation Technology, \tMedical Technology, etc.) Degrees Psychology (except Clinical Psychology, Physiological \tPsychology, Experimental Psychology which qualifying). Degrees Nursing. Degrees social sciences (Geography, Anthropology, Archaeology, etc.) Degrees Aviation, Aviation Management similar fields. Application Procedures ---------------------- Civilian application package obtained writing \tNASA Johnson Space Center \tAstronaut Selection Office \tATTN: \tHouston, 77058 Civilian applications will accepted continuous basis. When NASA decides select additional astronaut candidates, consideration will given only those applications hand date decision made. Applications received after that date will retained considered next selection. Applicants will notified annually opportunity update their applications indicate continued interest being considered program. Those applicants update their applications annually will dropped from consideration, their applications will retained. After preliminary screening applications, additional information requested some applicants, person listed application supervisors references contacted. Active Duty Military Active duty military personnel must submit applications their respective military service directly NASA. Application procedures will disseminated each service. Selection --------- Personal interviews thorough medical evaluations will required both civilian military applicants under final consideration. Once final selections have been made, applicants were considered will notified outcome process. Selection rosters established through this process used selection additional candidates during year period following their establishment. General Program Requirements Selected applicants will designated Astronaut Candidates will assigned Astronaut Office Johnson Space Center, Houston, Texas. astronaut candidates will undergo year training evaluation period during which time they will assigned technical scientific responsibilities allowing them contribute substantially ongoing programs. They will also participate basic astronaut training program which designed develop knowledge skills required formal mission training upon selection flight. Pilot astronaut candidates will maintain proficiency NASA aircraft during their candidate period. Applicants should aware that selection astronaut candidate does insure selection astronaut. Final selection astronaut will depend satisfactory completion year training evaluation period. Civilian candidates successfully complete training evaluation selected astronauts will become permanent Federal employees will expected remain with NASA period least five years. Civilian candidates selected astronauts placed other positions within NASA depending upon Agency requirements manpower constraints that time. Successful military candidates will detailed NASA specified tour duty. NASA affirmative action program goal having qualified minorities women among those qualified astronaut candidates. 'Australian Pattern Recognition Society CALL PAPERS DICTA-93 Conference DIGITAL IMAGING COMPUTING: TECHNIQUES APPLICATIONS Location: Macquarie Theatre Macquarie University Sydney Date: 8-10 December 1993. DICTA-93 second biennial national conference Australian Pattern Recognition Society. This event will provide opportunity persons with interest computer vision, digital image processing/analysis other aspects pattern recognition become informed about contemporary developments area, exchange ideas, establish contacts share details their work with others. Following invited speakers will provide specialised presentations: Prof Gabor Herman, University Pennsylvania Medical Imaging. Prof. R.M. Hodgson, Massey University Zealand Computer Vision. Prof. Dominique Juelin, Centre Morphologie Mathematique, Paris Mathematical Morphology. Prof. John Richards, Aust. Defence Force Academy, Canberra Remote Sensing. Phillip Robertson, CSIRO Division Information Technology, Canberra Interactive Visualisation. conference will concentrate (but limited following areas image processing:- Computer Vision Object Recognition Motion Analysis Morphology Medical Imaging Fuzzy logic Neural Networks Image Coding Machine Vision Robotics Enhancement Restoration Enhancement Restoration Visualisation Industrial Applications Software Hardware Tools Papers sought presentation conference publication conference proceedings. Submission peer review should consist extended abstract 750-1000 words doubled spaced text, summarizing technical aspects paper results that will quoted. Final papers should limited more than pages text illustrations camera-ready form. Four copies abstract should sent DICTA-93 Tony Adriaansen CSIRO Division Wool Technology Ryde 2112 Australia IMPORTANT DATES Abstract 25th June 1993 Acceptance notified 27th August 1993 Final paper 15th October 1993 SOCIAL PROGRAM: conference dinner will held Thursday December 1993. Other social activities being arranged. Situated beautiful harbour, Sydney many varied places interest. Opera House Harbour Bridge just well known landmarks. Harbour cruises, city tours Blue Mountains daily. provide further information request. ACCOMMODATION: Accommodation within walking distance available, ranging from college style star Hotel facilities. Information will supplied upon request. CONFERENCE FEES: before 30th Sep. After 30th Sep.
